title: Mohiniyattam
hero_image_alt: Mohiniyattam dancer in white and gold saree
short_description: A solo dance form from Kerala characterized by swaying movements and elegant white-and-gold costumes.
long_description:
Mohiniyattam, literally interpreting as the 'Dance of the Enchantress' (Mohini), is a classical solo dance form from Kerala. Legend says Lord Vishnu took the form of Mohini to enchant the demons and retrieve the nectar of immortality. 

The dance is characterized by 'Andolika' (swaying) movements that resemble palm leaves swaying in the breeze or waves of the ocean. It adheres to the Lasya style (graceful, feminine). The costume is a distinct white saree with gold borders (Kasavu), and the hair is tied in a side bun. It sits somewhere between the vigor of Kathakali and the structure of Bharatanatyam.
costume_and_makeup: White or off-white Kasavu saree with gold brocade. Hair gathered in a side bun (Kuduma) adorned with jasmine. Minimal but defining makeup.
